caseNameFull: Harry Dulfon, C. v. Aertsen P. Keasbey

opinions.snippet:
Robert A. Keasbey, a resident of Essex county, died June 22d 1927. His will bears date October 15th, 1923. His widow and two of his sons, Aertsen and R. Quinton Keasbey, are living. His son, Keith W. Keasbey, resident of California, died June 4th, 1931, leaving a wife, who was living with him at his death, and an adopted child, Roy Waldemar Keasbey, infant, adopted under the laws of California, September *Page 226 
10th, 1924, approximately nine months aft

posture:
Robert A. Keasbey, by the fourth paragraph of his last will and testament, gave the residue of his estate to his executors in trust to pay, out of the income, $10,000 yearly to his widow for life, a percentage of the income to two legatees, and:

"(e) All the balance of my said income remaining in the hands of my trustees after making the payments provided for in items b, c and d of this paragraph, I direct my executors and trustees to divide equally between my sons, Keith W. Keasbey, R. Quinton Keasbey and Aertsen P. Keasbey, until the death of my wife. In case any of my said sons should predecease my wife and leave lawful issue I direct my trustees to pay over to his children, share and share alike, his share of the income, provided they shall or any of them shall have attained the age of twenty-one years. For such grandchildren who have not attained the age of twenty-one years, I direct my said trustees to use, in their discretion, so much of the income that would belong to such deceased son or sons for the support, comfort and education of his or their children. Any unused balance of the income I direct be paid by my said trustees to the legal guardians of such children so that the grandchildren will each enjoy an equal share thereof,  per stirpes  and not  per capita.  Should any of my sons predecease his mother leaving no children but leaving a wife, I direct that my said trustees pay over one-third of such
deceased son's share of this balance of income to his widow so long as she remains his widow, and add the remaining two-thirds to the shares of my surviving sons.

"(f) On the death of my wife, I direct my executors and trustees to terminate the trust, and at that time, or at my death in case I survive my said wife, I dispose all of my residuary estate not heretofore disposed of, as follows:

" Fifth:  Item 1. (Annuity for Louise Pothier.)

"Item 2. (Annuity to two nephews.)

"Item 3. All the balance of my said estate, after paying the legacies and setting out the trust hereinbefore set forth, on the death of my wife, or at my death in case I survive my wife, I direct my executors to divide into four equal shares, and I direct that the amount of any indebtedness of any of my sons to me or my estate be added to the balance of my estate for the purpose of calculating the respective shares, and the amounts of such indebtedness, if any, be charged against the respective shares of my sons.

"One of such shares I direct my executors to divide into parts equal in number to the number of my grandchildren who may be living at the time this division takes place, plus one extra part for each of such grandchildren who may be a granddaughter. I direct my executors hereinafter named to set apart one such part for each grandson and two such parts for each of my granddaughters, and the several funds thus established I give, devise and bequeath to my executors hereinafter named, or their successors, in trust, however, to collect the income from each of the separate funds, and to pay the same, from time to time, after deduction of proper charges and expenses, to the guardians of my several grandchildren, until they reach the age of twenty-one years, and thereafter to the grandchildren themselves until they reach the age of twenty-five years. In case no legal guardian shall have qualified for any given one of my minor grandchildren, I authorize and empower my trustees to pay the income to either of the parents of such grandchild, or directly to such grandchild, and I direct that a receipt or quittance for funds so paid shall be a discharge  pro tanto  to my trustees. Furthermore, at the written request of the living parents or parent of any of my said grandchildren, endorsed by the grandchild, if he or she be over the age of fourteen years, I authorize my trustees to pay bills out of the principal, where the income prove insufficient, for the support, comfort or education of my several grandchildren.

"As my grandchildren shall severally reach the age of twenty-five years, I direct that the balance of the several funds, principal and income, be paid to them. Should any of my grandchildren die after this clause of my will takes effect, I direct that the balance of the fund belonging to such grandchild be disposed of as he or she may direct by will duly probated, or, failing such direction or appointment, be paid to their next of kin, as determined by the laws of the State of New Jersey at the date of the death of such grandchild.

"I desire to state that in the term `grandchild' or `grandchildren' I do not include any great grandchildren.

"One of the remaining shares I give, devise and bequeath to each of my three sons who may be living at the time of the division. In case any of my sons shall have died, leaving a wife with whom he was living at the time of his death, I direct that she be paid, and I hereby give, devise and bequeath to her, one-third of the amount that her husband would have received, had he survived both his mother and myself, provided she shall not have remarried at the time this provision takes effect. In case any of my sons shall have died when this provision takes effect, leaving issue, I give, devise and bequeath the share that such deceased son would have taken (less the one-third thereof to be paid to his wife if he leave a wife qualified to take under this clause of my will) to his issue, share and share alike,  per  stirpes  and not  per capita.  In case any of my sons die before this paragraph of my will takes effect, leaving no issue, I direct that the share he would have received (less one-third thereof if he leave a wife qualified to take) be added to the other two shares of my estate set apart for my sons, to be disposed of as such shares are herein disposed of."

On bill for construction of will.

opinions.snippet:
I respectfully dissent from the opinion of the majority. It is erroneous in two important points that control the decision: First, in its ruling that the neurosis from which petitioner suffered as described in Dr. Cline's testimony is compensable; and second, in its conclusion that Dr. Cline expressed the opinion that petitioner's neurosis directly resulted from the damage done to the physical structure of his body in the accident.
It will be necessary to make a more complete explanati

posture:
Error to the Court of Civil Appeals for the Fourth District, in an appeal from Nueces County.

This suit was brought by Owen B. Hood against the Texas Indemnity Insurance Company to recover workmen's compensation for an injury received in the course of his employment with Montgomery Ward  Company, in the City of Corpus Christi. Other facts are stated in the opinion. The trial court rendered judgment for the plaintiff, which judgment was reformed by the Court of Civil Appeals, amounting in effect to a reversal of the trial court's judgment and the rendition of a judgment in favor of the defendant,  208 S.W.2d 658 . Plaintiff Hood has brought error to the Supreme Court.

Judgment of the Court of Civil Appeals is reversed and that
of the trial court affirmed. Justices Smedley, Brewster and Folley dissenting.

judge: Head, Henderson, Kefhart, Porter, Qrladt, Trexler, Williams

opinions.snippet:
Opinion by
Head, J.,
In and by the fifth paragraph of his will the testator provided as follows: “I give, devise and bequeath to my wife......all the rest and remainder of my estate...... for the term of her natural life with full power and authority to sell or use any part of my estate for her own individual benefit or for any purpose whatever as she shall think proper without being compelled to go into th

syllabus:
Decedents’ estates — Wills—Construction—Devise of remainder with power to resume — Intention of testator.

Where the testator devised the remainder of his estate to his wife for the term of her natural life, with full power and authority to sell and use any part of it for her own use without being compelled to go into the orphans’ court for permission to make such disposition, giving her full authority to make deeds, etc., for the property which she desired to sell, but subsequently made various provisions of his estate to take effect after the death of his wife, the language of the will must be held to contemplate a gift to the widow for life of the entire residue of the estate, with power to sell any portion of such residue, even to the extent of exhausting it. At most it must be held to be a gift in posse only, and not in esse, which would actually come into being only after subsequent and affirmative exercise by her of the power conferred upon her under the will.

Decedents’ estates — Inheritance taxes — Act of July 11, 1917, P. L. 882.

When the intention of a testator, as deduced from the terms of his will, was to give to his wife an estate for life with a power to consume, an appraisement for the purposes of determining the direct inheritance tax due, should ascertain the value of such life estate. Under such circumstances the direct tax should only be paid on the life estate.

opinions.snippet:
Opinion by
Henderson, J.,
The plaintiff’s action is for damages for the wrongful diversion of water from a public highway onto his land by the supervisors of the township. His allegation is that a ditch was cut along the side of the road through an elevation of the ground, thirty years ago or more, by means of which the surface water accumulating on the road and adjacent land Was carried down the road and away

syllabus:
Road law — Diversion of water from road — Public road — Supervisors— Discretion.

Where supervisors open a drain along the side of a public road, and waters which naturally flowed from the road on to the lands of an adjoining owner, are carried off by the drain, and this condition of things exists for many years, a subsequent board of supervisors is not precluded thereby from closing up the drain, and again diverting the water on to the neighboring land, if they do so in the exercise of a proper discretion. In such a case the neighboring owner never acquired a right to use the road as a conduit to carry the water from his premises.
